   .
   This 70-year-old man has had a witnessed cardiac arrest at home with
   CRP by his daughter at the scene. VF was noted in EMS. He was rapidly
   cooled, but his neurologic unresponsiveness and myoclonus is concerning
   for severe hypoxic injury. The etiology of this presentation is
   unclear.
   .
   PLAN
   .
   Coma
     GCS 3. Spinal relexes 3+ now, mute plantar, without brainstem
   reflexes. However, appropriate respiratory drive given pH and CO2,
   suggesting brainstem respiratory circuitry largely intact. EEG still
   quite isoelectric with some beta with benzodiazepines. Return of burst
   suppression pattern when Versed and fentanyl were held this morning.
   Also some generalized myoclonic jerks. Altogether some recovery seen
   (spinal reflexes and only minimal ataxic breathing at presentation),
   but little and prognosis likely still bad. Neurology are following and
   will help prognosticate/manage. Family aware of these thoughts,
   broadly.
   - EEG overnight or 48 hours
   - Appreciate Neurology input with respect to EEG
   - Continue cooling for 12 - 24 hours, per protocol, then re-evaluate
   neurologic status as rewarmed, sedation and paralysis weaned.
   - Stop dilantin, per later recs from Neurlogy team.
   .
   Cardiorespiratory (VF?) Arrest
     Differential diagnosis includes arhythmia, pulmonary embolism,
   myocardial ischemia, perhaps resulting in arhythmia, toxic. CTA was
   negative on wet read, ischemia appears not to be profound, given
   enzymes and EKG, toxicity is possible. Arhythmia is possible,
   particularly if digoxin was being taken incorrectly, if too much
   methylphenidate was being taken (he was recorded as taking 20 mg).
   Given low level of digoxin (0.7) and history of non-compliance with
   glipizide dosing (per PCP), medication non-compliance or error is also
   possible. He takes three anti-arhythmic medications (atenolol,
   diltiazem and digoxin). Was likely VF arrest based on EMS report. Given
   that he struck his head, likely arrhythmia (sudden LOC).
   - Telemetry
   - Was on diltiazem 300 mg/d and atenolol 100 mg/d, so may need to add
   some block back
   - metoprolol 5 mg IV q4h
   .
   Arhythmia, Ventricular ectopy
     Substantial ventricular ectopy, short runs of VT. Patient takes
   diltiazem, atenolol, digoxin at home. Given frequent ectopy will add
   back small doses, given cooling.
   - Metoprolol 5 mg IV q4h
   - Hold digoxin, diltiazem
   - Telemetry
   - EKG in a.m.
   - Hold warfarin - supratherapeutic

 hold

   - Hold antihypertensives (enalapril, atenolol, diltiazem)
